subsection.title: 1. Find the slope of a line

introduction.p: We can tell whether two lines are parallel, perpendicular, or neither by comparing their slopes.

statement.p: Find the slope of the line ~6x-8y = 9

solution.p: The easiest way to find the slope of this line is to put its equation into slope-intercept form by solving for y. -8y \amp = -6x+9 y \amp = \dfrac{-6x+9}{-8} = \dfrac{3}{4}x - \dfrac{9}{8} The slope of the line is \dfrac{3}{4}.

statement.p: Find the slope of the line whose intercepts are (112,0) and (0,140).

solution.p: We use the slope formula. m = \dfrac{y_2-y_1}{x_2-x_1} = \dfrac{140-0}{0-112} = \dfrac{140}{-112} = \dfrac{-5}{4}

introduction.p: Analytic geometry uses algebra to help solve geometric problems.

stack.p: The figure shows isosceles triangle ABC and its altitude \overline{AP}. (Recall that the altitude of a triangle is the segment perpendicular to the base that passes through the opposite vertex.) For this problem, we'll use the following property:
In an isoceles triangle, the altitude bisects the base.

ol.label: a
ol.li: Find the equation of the line that includes \overline{AP}.
Find the coordinates of point P.
Find the length of the segment \overline{AP}.

li.p: Because the altitude bisects the base, point P is the midpoint of \overline{BC}. The coordinates of B and C are (6,0) and (2,-6), so we use the midpoint formula to find the coordinates of P. x \amp = \dfrac{-2+6}{2} = 2 y \amp = \dfrac{-6+0}{2} = -3 The coordinates of P are (2,-3).
The coordinates of P are (2,-3), and the coordinates of A are (-4,5). We use the distance formula to find the length of \overline{AP}. \overline{AP} = \sqrt{(-4-2)^2+(5+3)^2} = \sqrt{36+64} = 10
